subject: Re: [junit] Atomic vs Childless
msgSnippet: Dani, The higher-level philosophical question demands an answer--is there a difference between a stand-alone test, and a parent test node with all its children
messageBody:
Dani,

The higher-level philosophical question demands an answer--is there a
difference between a stand-alone test, and a parent test node with all
its children removed (probably yes), and is that represented in the
Description tree (not really). I'd like to see where our current work
on the 4.4 branch is going, and then see how we can best answer those.

However, in your particular situation, I think there's no need for
concern. Since you're delegating to TestClassRunner, you should
always be able to assume that the description you get would have
children if unfiltered. That is, TestClassRunner does not interpret
any test classes as being atomic tests.

Perhaps I've missed a corner case--please let me know, if so.

David Saff

On 3/22/07, Dani Zweig <dani@...> wrote:
>
> My custom runner filters out some test methods. However, if all the methods
> in a class are filtered out, the runner will issue a no-tests failure. (I'd
> like to continue delegating to TestClassRunner.) The following
> implementation of run() would work for the no-tests-active case, but it
> would also fail to run an atomic test:
>
> @Override
> public void run(RunNotifier notifier) {
> if (getDescription().getChildren().isEmpty()) {
> log("Warning: No active tests found for class " +
> getDescription());
> } else {
> delegate.run(notifier);
> }
> }
>
> Is there a way I can tell whether a test is atomic?
> (Description.testCount() is hard-coded to assume that a test with no
> children has a test count of 1.)
>
> tnx.
>
